question: 解ける
sourceAnswer:
to: be-{solved/resolved} | {loosen/come-untied/come-undone} | be-{removed-(of-restrictions)/lifted-(e.g.-a-ban)/broken-(spells,-curses,-etc.)} | {dissipate-(of-anger,-tension,-etc.)/melt-away/ease/be-appeased/be-resolved-(of-a-dispute,-misunderstanding,-etc.)/be-cleared-up}
<tag><ja>溶ける</ja></tag>:: to: melt/thaw/fuse | dissolve
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be solved</vocabulary>. You know that this is the version where something just unties on its own (you're not doing the untying) because you don't have a <reading>care</reading> (<ja>ける</ja>) in the world. You just watch things getting untied and don't do it yourself.
sourceReadingMnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In fact, while you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to become untied, you stare down at your <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>). Really imagine doing that while things around you are getting untied.
